event.p: This performance was broadcast on 22 November 1953 and televised on 6 December 1954.
This studio performance was broadcast on BBC Radio 3 on 18 December 1984.

annot.p: Thomas Beecham identified the subject of the opera as based on the legends of The Princess and the Swineherd and Irmelin, a pairing that allowed Delius to combine the creation of a Turandot-like fastidious heroine with contemplation of nature (ThB, 56-58). Like The Magic Fountain, Irmelin remained unperformed in Delius's lifetime, and was resurrected by Beecham. Both the subject matter and motifs from the work were taken up again by Delius in subsequent compositions, hence the large number of related works.

castItem.roleDesc: a prince, having lost his way, swineherd of Rolf

role.name: Chorus of Robbers, Knights, Guests, Women, Wood-Nymphs, Girls and Boys

relation.label: Is related to: Songs of Sunset

notesStmt.annot: Contained within a notebook of sketches, this item is a pencil sketch for part of the prelude to Act III of Irmelin, headed 'Vorspiel'.

physDesc.physMedium: A notebook consisting largely of short sketches for various sections of Irmelin.

notesStmt.annot: Brief sketch material in one bifolium, alongside material for Folkeraadet.
This source contains (i) a 'Prelude 1st Act', with some material resembling the theme of the Prelude to Act III of Irmelin and (ii) a sketch of the 'Silver Stream' motive from Act II.

This source was the score used by Beecham for the 1953 production, and contains his markings in blue pencil throughout. The item also contains the Irmelin Prelude (1931) in the hand of Eric Fenby, headed Prelude to the Opera Irmelin/Frederick Delius/1890. The score proper has no title page.
In this source, the voice parts, English words and stage directions are in Delius's hand and the piano part in that of Schmitt. An unidentified scribe has added German words in pencil throughout.

annot.p: This item is a dyeline copy of the vocal score prepared for Thomas Beecham for the first performance and publication. It is interleaved with paper containing many remarks relating to production; there are also annotations on the score. Threlfall reveals that Beecham made a number of modifications to the words in this version (DCE.RT, p. 29).

This source is the published version of Arundell's manuscript vocal score. It contains a list of errata and modifications to Delius's text. Threlfall indicates that while the manuscript closely follows Delius's original, this edition includes extra dynamics, metronome marks, and phrasing, which Threlfall attributes to Beecham (DCE 1: Irmelin, Preface).

notesStmt.annot: This volume forms part of the Collected Edition. It incorporates Beecham's editorial markings in the autograph score and some of his suggestions of replacements for archaisms in the libretto.
